messageBody:
So said tumb@... on 2002-12-13 --------------------

>Trying to define the public interface other than thru Java is a great
>idea!
>
>I've had the problem of making methods public (or package) for testing
>and then finding that other people on our team use them. One of the
key
>reasons is that if you're using a full featured IDE (JBuilder,
Eclipse,
>...), the IDE will offer your package methods to coders as possible
>methods. I think this is one of the problems that people mean when
they
>talk about 'polluting' an interface.

If you are adding elements to the public interface other than query
methods, then perhaps you need to change the design. If you need to
call otherwise private methods to set up state in a single object to
enable testing, then your objects are probably too large. Calling the
constructor ought to be enough.

So if you find that you need to add "just for testing" methods to your
public interface that change your object's state, that's a code smell.
You have many objects collaborating, rather than one.

Comments?
